contents:
What Is the role? We are looking for a personal financial planning pro (Certified Financial Planner™ preferred) who will lead our client advising efforts. You will be a fiduciary who works with clients providing holistic advice on areas including: saving, retirement, debt management, investments. You’ll be on the front lines helping clients in what is arguably the most important position at the company.
Why join Delta’s People team? We are especially interested in finding developers with experience either building web APIs with Go or experience with functional programming (e.g. Elixir, NodeJS, Clojure, F#). You might not have experience with all the technologies in our stack, but you are motivated to learn deeply. You will get the opportunity to work with both Go and Elixir with experienced team mates who can teach and pair with you to learn whatever you have less experience with.You care about security, code quality, scalability, performance, and simplicity. Above all, you seek operational excellence and apply the best engineering practices possible. Not everything that you or your team do can be perfect, but you make sure that you always know the trade-offs.
Some of the high impact opportunities you’ll tackle?  must keep passwords secure and confidential; are solely responsible for User Data and all activity in their account while using the Service; must use commercially reasonable efforts to prevent unauthorized access to their account, and notify Conclude promptly of any such unauthorized access; and may use the Service only in accordance with Conclude’s online user guide and all applicable laws and regulations.  Responsibilities  Enhance or improve User experience, our Site, or our Service. Process transactions. Send emails about our Site or respond to inquiries. As this Privacy Policy and our Terms of Service.  Requirements We are looking for a personal financial planning pro (Certified Financial Planner™ preferred) who will lead our client advising efforts. You will be a fiduciary who works with clients providing holistic advice on areas including: saving, retirement, debt
This opportunity is for you if you have/are:  Enhance or improve User experience, our Site, or our Service. Process transactions requests for agreement. Send emails about our Site or respond to inquiries. Send emails and updates about Conclude, including news and requests for agreement to amended legal documents such. As this Privacy Policy and our Terms of Service.

contents:
Table Of Content  Heading 2  Heading 3  Heading 4  Heading 5 Emphasis Link Paragraph Ordered List Unordered List Code and Syntax Highlighting Blockquote Inline HTML Tables Image Youtube video          Here is example of hedings. You can use this heading by following markdownify rules. For example: use # for heading 1 and use ###### for heading 6.
Heading 1 Heading 2 Heading 3 Heading 4 Heading 5 Heading 6  Emphasis Emphasis, aka italics, with asterisks or underscores.
Strong emphasis, aka bold, with asterisks or underscores.
Combined emphasis with asterisks and underscores.
Strikethrough uses two tildes. Scratch this.
 Link I’m an inline-style link
I’m an inline-style link with title
I’m a reference-style link
I’m a relative reference to a repository file
You can use numbers for reference-style link definitions
Or leave it empty and use the link text itself.
URLs and URLs in angle brackets will automatically get turned into links. http://www.example.com or http://www.example.com and sometimes example.com (but not on Github, for example).
Some text to show that the reference links can follow later.
 Paragraph Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet consectetur adipisicing elit. var s = "JavaScript syntax highlighting"; alert(s); s = "Python syntax highlighting" print s  Blockquote  This is a blockquote example.

 Definition list Is something people use sometimes. Markdown in HTML Does *not* work **very** well. Use HTML tags.   This is a simple note

  Tables Colons can be used to align columns.
   Tables Are Cool     col 3 is right-aligned $1600   col 2 is centered $12   zebra stripes are neat $1    There must be at least 3 dashes separating each header cell. The outer pipes (|) are optional, and you don’t need to make the raw Markdown line up prettily. You can also use inline Markdown.

Evolve and modernize your Java code for longer-lasting, more sustainable software. Download the latest version of CodeModernizer for Mac, Linux, or Windows. After the download CodeModernizer will check your license key to see what version of the software you have decided to use.
🍎 Download for Mac
🖼️ Download for Windows
🐧 Download for Linux
[Screenshots] https://www.codemodernizer.com/images/undraw/undraw_server_re_twwj.svg does not exist  Installation & Tutorial There are a couple of steps you need to go through to download CodeModernizer:
 Download the latest version of CodeModernizer for your operating system of choice. Buy a license for CodeModernizer over at our Buy page. Download the license you get sent by mail after paying. Run CodeModernizer  Visit Resources for more information on the installation of CodeModernizer.

title: Joseph Gonzalez

contents:
CodeModernizer is a product and service from IBTECH BV, a limited liability company under Belgian law. It makes use of the e2immu.org open source static code analyzer for Java.
Data protection [ legal way of saying we will only use your data for necessary uses + GDPR ]
Protection of your code In summary, there are two ways the CodeModernizer software can be used.
 Firstly, you can just download CodeModernizer, pay for a license, and get going. Individuals or companies opting for this option will have a guarantee that IBTECH will never get the chance to see the code that CodeModernizer analyzes since the code transformer and standard transformation library can be run locally inside of your own organization, using our binary. The binary writes to a different branch of the source code management system, and we guarantee that the binary does not communicate over the internet, so your code is as secure as it can be. If you opt for custom work for your specific situation, IBTECH will need to have a view on the parts of the code that need modernizing. A non-disclosure agreement will be signed if such a view is to be granted. For more information concerning consulting, and data protection in that case, send us a mail over at info@codemodernizer.com
title: Legal

contents:
On this page I’m presenting a selection of transformation examples, ranging from the rather trivial to the more complicated. The goal is each time to end up with code that makes use of modern constructs, and is easier to understand.
Old loop constructs It is obvious that we want very old constructs out of the way:
Enumeration<E> enumeration = vector.elements(); while (enumeration.hasMoreElements()) {  E e = enumeration.nextElement();  accept(e); } is much more verbose than
vector.forEach(accept); Some coders may even have written
for (Enumeration<E> e = v.elements(); e.hasMoreElements();)  accept(e.nextElement()); which does take me a second to parse.
I am more accustomed to iterators and lists, rather than enumerations and vectors,
Iterator<E> it = list.iterator(); while(it.hasNext()) {  E e = it.next();  accept(e); } but obviously
list.forEach(accept) remains the easiest to understand.
These examples were focused on conciseness of code: the most compact one is also the one requiring the least mental efforts to understand. But sometimes the loop may hide a real problem:
for(int i=0; i<=vector.size(); i++) {  accept(vector.get(i)); } Oops, that = should not have been there. While
for(int i=0; i<vector.size(); i++) {  accept(vector.get(i)); } is not such a performance hit, the same construct using a generic List instance may be slow when the underlying implementation is a LinkedList:
for(int i=0; i<list.size(); i++) {  accept(list.get(i)); } Conditional return Sometimes, it is simply a matter of aesthetics:
if(i < 3) {  return -1; } return 1; or
if(i < 3) {  return -1; } else {  return 1; } or
return i < 3 ? -1 : 1 But what if a method call is involved? Is
boolean b = someMethod(); if(c) {  return true; } return b; equivalent to
if(c) {  return true; } return someMethod(); or even
return c || someMethod() This is where e2immu comes into play: it all depends on whether the method is modifying or not. If someMethod modifies the state of this, then it must be called before returning, and
return someMethod() || c; will be correct. If it is not modifying, but, on the contrary, a time-consuming operation, it’d be silly not to swap the || clauses, to conditionally avoid a lengthy call.
Final fields In this rather trivial example, I’d prefer to see a final modifier to count:
public class Count {   private int count;   public Count(int input) {  this.count = input;  }   public int getCount() {  return count;  } } It’d be easier to use
public record Count(int count) {} but then you’ll have to swap out getCount() for count() everywhere in your code. A small modification brings me back from modernization to regularization:
public class Count {   private int count;   public Count(int input) {  if(input == -1) {  this.count = someComputation(input);  } else {  this.count = input;  }  this.count = this.count + 1; // let's start counting from 1  }   public int getCount() {  return count;  } } This constructor doesn’t allow the final modifier, because count is assigned to more than once. After a regularization step not unlike the one discussed in a previous section, we’re back to a single assignment:
public class Count {   private final int count;   public Count(int input) {  this.count = (input == -1 ? someComputation(input) : input) + 1;  }   public int getCount() {  return count;  } } I cannot stress enough the importance of being able to see that count will not change during the lifetime of the object.

title: Privacy & Policy

contents:
Right now, CodeModernizer is still in development. No downloadable software is yet available. However, we do have a roadmap and timeline with the goals of where we want CodeModernizer to be in the future.
 By the 4th quarter of 2022, custom consulting jobs can be done for companies interested in the services CodeModernizer offers. The CodeModernizer will be be used internally where applicable. By the summer of 2023, a first downloadable version should be available for early adopters. By the end of 2023, CodeModernizer will be available at full price for the first time.
title: Roadmap / Timeline

contents: This page delves deeper into the technical workings of CodeModernizer, for curious developers.
title: Technical Details

contents:
Mission and Vision  Our mission is to make a lasting impact on the programming world by offering tools that help code lasts longer and be more maintainable, and hence, sustainable.
 Code and software development is not often focused on the longer term. However, the model of building systems that only last a couple of years, and that then have to be redesigned, rewritten and replaced, is far from sustainable and efficient.
Even though the (Java) programming world is constantly evolving and changing, this should not mean the code has to lose value and become outdated. Older code generally has fewer bugs and a lot of domain knowledge has been incorporated over time. Replacing it with new code just because the existing code is becoming ‘old’ is inefficient, wasteful of time and resources, and almost always more expensive.
As the programming language evolves over time, so do the programmers. Younger and newly trained programmers might not easily recognize old software patterns, and also don’t feel motivated to try to figure out code that hasn’t been updated for decades. We propose to evolve the code with the language and the programmers, so that it does not have to be replaced. Rather, it can last decades by repeatedly modernizing it. At the same time, these modernization transformations are instructive: programmers can also learn from the changes CodeModernizer proposes.
 Our vision is to help standardize and transform code so that it can last for decades, and to educate both beginning and experienced programmers.
 Sustainability Through Software What do we mean with sustainability through software? Creating software that survives trends and retains its value. Sustainable software, at the same time, also concerns the use of resources. Not having to manually re-write code not only saves human resources, but also saves energy. Using existing code offers other advantages, like the fact that the finer details of the code are conserved, which in turn saves even more time and resources.
Another way in which we can make code more efficient, and longer lasting, is by making it more compact and readable. A good code base should last through multiple, different generations of programmers at a company. If the code is kept compact, readable, and up-to-date, lots of time and precious resources can be preserved when new coders have to take over the work of the existing ones.
Education, Open Source, and Sharing of Knowledge Education is one of the core values of CodeModernizer. The use of our tools is not only beneficial for the source code as an asset, but also for the developers themselves. The world of Java programming is ever evolving and changing, and it is impossible for every developer to keep up with every new trend, library, feature, etc. Programmers who use CodeModernizer are able to see ways in which their code can be improved upon, which also helps them to keep evolving and learning as software engineers.
At the same time we also want to give back to the open source community that has been the backbone of the programming world for years. The amount of software projects that have been realized with the help of open source software is countless, and the world wouldn’t be the same without them.
We want as much people using the software as possible, even if they do not necessarily have the funds to do so. That’s why we will offer our software for free to students, people employed at educational institutions, and software developers actively working on an open source project.
Support for Open Source Our support for open source goes even further: CodeModernizer is based on the e2immu.org project, an open source static code analyzer that focuses on modification and immutability. If you want to get your hands dirty yourself, why not try using e2immu? Even better, you may be able to contribute to the project itself.
title: Values
